Award.AwardTitle: Wind River Conference on Procaryotic Biology-Student Support to be held in summers of 2010, 2011, and 2012 at the Lodge in Estes Park Colorado

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: This award provides support for the Wind River Conference on Procaryotic Biology (formerly the Wind River Conference on Genetic Exchange; Transformation Meetings). The 2010 meeting will be held June 2-6 in Estes Park, Colorado. This annual international meeting is devoted to the biology of a variety of procaryotic systems and includes reports of research in the fields of procaryotic gene regulation, molecular biology, physiology, genetic exchange, procaryotic biology and related areas, including DNA repair/mutagenesis/evolution, procaryotic differentiation and developmental pathways, recombination pathways, thermophilic biology, archaeal biology, and biotechnology. The diversity of systems represented by the meeting provide a fertile environment for sharing of new ideas and for applying well-established concepts to newly emerging systems.

Broader Impacts: Historically, a strength of this meeting has been a commitment to including participation by graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and even some very talented undergraduate researchers. This grant will foster this tradition by allowing these young researchers to present their research in oral and poster presentations, discuss their work with nationally and internationally recognized leaders in the field, and begin to build their own professional networks.

This conference is co-funded by Genes and Genome Systems, Biomolecular Systems, and Cellular Systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award from NSF was used to help fund student researchers (graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and undergraduates) to attend the annual Wind River Conference on Procaryotic Biology. This conference has been in existence for over 50 years and is a national/international meeting in which the students have a real opportunity to present their own research (oral presentations as well as posters). The students attending these meetings not only present their research but, they have that research critiqued by leading researchers in the various fields represented by procaryotic biology.

The meeting programs have been set up such that there is additional time for students to discuss a variety of topics in procaryotic biology that are normally not part of standard classroom material. Thus, these meetings enhance the depth and breath of knowledge of the students with respect to environmental microbiology, industrial microbiology, molecular microbiology, microbial genetics, agriculture and plant microbiology, evolution, pathogenic mechanisms, microbial ecology, etc.

One of the most rewarding aspects of these conferences has been the willingness of established researchers to spend considerable amounts of time with the student researchers. These interactions has been invaluable in shaping many of the students’ interests and goals. Also, an emphasis has been placed upon the importance of researchers communicating the relevance of their work to the general public.
